tn.text: This is the next part of the story. Judas agrees to betray Jesus. These verses give background information about this part of the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This word is used here to introduce a new part of the story.

The festival was called by this name because during the festival, the Jews did not eat bread that was made with yeast. AT: "festival when they would eat unleavened bread" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"was almost ready to begin"

tn.ref: how they could put Jesus to death
tn.text: The priests and scribes did not have the authority to kill Jesus themselves, but they hoped to get others to kill him. AT: "how they might cause Jesus to be put to death" or "how they could cause someone to kill Jesus"
Possible meanings are 1) "scared of what the people might do" or 2) "scared that the people would make Jesus king."
This is the beginning of the action in this part of the story.
This was probably very similar to demon possession.
"the leaders of the priests"
"officers of the temple guards" (UDB)

tn.ref: how he would betray Jesus to them
tn.text: "how he would help them arrest Jesus"
"The chief priests and captains"
"to give Judas money"
"agreed"

tn.ref: looked for an opportunity to deliver him to them away from the crowd
tn.text: This is an on-going action that continues after this part of the story ends. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_endofstory]])
"to help them arrest Jesus"
"privately" or "when there was no crowd around him" (UDB)

This is the next part of the story. Jesus sends Peter and John to prepare for the Passover meal. Verse 7 gives background information about the setting of the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"The day of bread without yeast." This was the day the Jews would take all bread made with yeast out of their homes. Then they would celebrate the Festival of Unleavened Bread for seven days.

tn.ref: the Passover lamb must be sacrificed
tn.text: Each family or group of people would kill a lamb and eat it together, so many lambs were killed. This can be stated in active form. AT: "people had to kill the lamb for the Passover meal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is a general word meaning "make ready." Jesus was not necessarily telling Peter and John to do all the cooking.

tn.ref: so that we may eat it
tn.text: Jesus was including Peter and John when he said "we." Peter and John would be part of the group of the disciples that would eat the meal. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: you want us to make preparations
tn.text: The word "us" does not include Jesus. Jesus would not be part of the group that would prepare the meal. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
"make preparations for the meal" or "prepare the meal"
"Jesus answered Peter and John"
Jesus used this word to tell them to pay close attention and to do exactly what he tells them.

tn.ref: a man bearing a pitcher of water will meet you
tn.text: "you will see a man carrying a pitcher of water"
"carrying a jar with water in it." He probably would have carried the jar on his shoulder.
"Follow him, and go into the house"

This begins a direct quotation where Jesus tells the disciples what they should say. The UDB renders this as an indirect quotation: "Our teacher says to show us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
This refers to Jesus.
"eat the Passover meal"
Jesus continues giving instructions to Peter and John.
"The owner of the house will show you"
"room upstairs." If your community does not have houses with rooms above other rooms, you may need to consider how to describe buildings in the city.
"So Peter and John went"
this is the next event in the part of the story about the Passover. Jesus and his disciples are sitting to eat the Passover meal.
"When it was time to eat the meal" (UDB)
"Jesus sat down"
"I have wanted very much" (UDB)
Jesus is referring ahead to his death. The word for "suffer" here refers to an unusually difficult or painful experience.
Jesus uses this phrase to emphasize the importance of what he will say next.

This can be stated in active form. Possible meanings are 1) until the purpose of the Passover Festival is accomplished. AT: "until God fulfills it" or "until God completes the purpose of the Passover Festival" or 2) "until we celebrate the final Passover Festival" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"picked up a cup of wine"
"when he had given thanks to God"
"he said to his apostles"

They were to share the contents of the cup, and not the cup itself. AT: "share the wine in the cup among yourselves" or "each of you drink some of the wine from the cup" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This phrase is used to emphasize the importance of what Jesus will say next.
This refers to the juice that is squeezed from the grapes that grow on grapevines. Wine is made from fermented grape juice.

tn.ref: until the kingdom of God comes
tn.text: "until God establishes his kingdom" or "until God rules in his kingdom"
This bread did not have yeast in it, so it was flat.

"he ripped it" or "he tore it." He may have divided it into many pieces or he may have divided it into two pieces and given them to the apostles to divide among themselves. If possible, use an expression that would apply to either situation.
Possible meanings are 1) "This bread is my body" and 2) "This bread represents my body."

tn.ref: my body which is given for you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "my body, which I will give for you" or "my body, which I will sacrifice for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Eat this bread"
"in order to remember me"
The word "cup" refers to the wine in the cup. AT: "The wine in this cup" or "This cup of wine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the new covenant in my blood
tn.text: This new covenant will take effect as soon his blood is shed. AT: "the new covenant the will be ratified through my blood"

tn.ref: my blood, which is poured out for you
tn.text: Jesus spoke of his death by referring to his blood being poured out. AT: "my blood, which is poured out in death for you" or "my blood, which will flow out of my wounds for you when I die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Jesus continues speaking to his apostles.
"The one who will betray me"

tn.ref: For the Son of Man indeed goes
tn.text: "For, indeed, the Son of Man will go" or "For the Son of Man will die"
Jesus is speaking about himself in the third person. AT: "I, the Son of Man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "as God has determined" or "as God has planned" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: But woe to that man through whom he is betrayed!
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "But woe to the man who betrays the Son of Man!" or "But how terrible it will be for that man who betrays the Son of Man!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Then there arose also a quarrel among them
tn.text: "Then the apostles began to argue among themselves" (UDB)
This can be stated in active form. AT: "the people would think was most important" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Jesus said to the apostles"
"rule harshly over the Gentiles" or "like to exercise power over them"
The people probably did not think of those rulers as people who do good to their people. AT: "like to be called" or "call themselves"
Jesus continues teaching his apostles.

tn.ref: it must not be like this with you
tn.text: "you should not act like that"

Older people were respected in that culture. The leaders were usually older people and were called "elders." The youngest person would be the least likely to lead, and the least important. AT: "the least important" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"a servant"
This connects Jesus' commands in verse 26 with the whole of verse 27. It means that the most important person should serve because Jesus is a servant.

"For who is more important ... serves?" Jesus uses this question to begin to explain to the apostles who is truly great. AT: "I want you to think about who is greater ... serves." ([[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: the one who sits at the table
tn.text: "the one who is dining"

tn.ref: Is it not the one who sits at the table?
tn.text: Jesus uses another question to teach the disciples. AT: "Of course the one who sits at the table is more important than the servant!" ([[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Yet I am among you as one who serves
tn.text: "But I am serving you." The word "yet" is here because there is a contrast between what people would expect Jesus to be like and what he really was like.

tn.ref: have continued with me in my temptations
tn.text: "have stayed with me through my struggles"

tn.ref: I give to you a kingdom, even as my Father has given a kingdom to me
tn.text: Some languages may need to change the order. AT: "Just as my father has given a kingdom to me, I give it to you"

tn.ref: I give to you a kingdom
tn.text: "I make you rulers in God's kingdom" or "I give you authority to rule in the kingdom" or "I will make you kings"

tn.ref: even as my Father has given a kingdom to me
tn.text: "just as my Father has given me authority to rule as king in his kingdom"
Kings sit on thrones. Sitting on a throne is a symbol of ruling. AT: "you will work as kings" or "you will do the work of kings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Jesus speaks directly to Simon.
Jesus said his name twice to show that what he was about to say to him was very important.

tn.ref: to have you, that he might sift you
tn.text: The word "you" refers to all of the apostles. Languages that have different forms of "you" should use the plural form. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This means that Satan wanted to test the disciples to find something wrong. AT: "test you like someone passes grain through a sieve" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: But I have prayed for you
tn.text: The word "you" here refers specifically to Simon. Languages that have different forms of you should use the singular form. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: that your faith may not fail
tn.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "that you will continue to have faith" or "that you will continue to trust me"

tn.ref: After you have turned back again
tn.text: "After you start following me again" or "After you start serving me again"
"encourage your brothers to be strong in their faith" or "help your brothers believe in me"
This refers to the other disciples. AT: "your fellow believers" or "the other disciples"

tn.ref: the rooster will not crow this day, before you deny three times that you know me
tn.text: The order of the parts of the verse can be reversed: "You will deny three times that you know me before the rooster crows this day."

tn.ref: the rooster will not crow this day, before you deny
tn.text: This can be stated positively. AT: "the rooster will crow this day only after you deny"

Here, the crowing of the rooster refers to a certain time of day. Roosters often crow just before the sun appears in the morning. Therefore, this refers to dawn. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The Jewish day begins at sunset. Jesus was speaking after the sun had set. The rooster would crow just before morning. The morning was part of "this day." AT: "tonight" or "in the morning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Jesus turns his attention back to speaking to all of his disciples.

Jesus uses a question to help the apostles remember how well the people provided for them as they traveled. AT: "Remember that when ... you had everything you needed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Jesus was talking to his apostles. So languages that have different forms of "you" should use the plural form. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
A purse is a bag for holding money. Here it is used to refer to "money." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"travelers' bag" or "bag of food"
It may be helpful to some audiences to include more about the conversation. AT: "We did not lack anything" or "We had everything we needed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: The one who does not have a sword should sell his cloak
tn.text: Jesus was not referring to a specific person who did not have a sword. AT: "If anyone does not have a sword, he should sell his cloak"
"coat" or "outer garment"
Jesus finishes speaking with his disciples.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "what a prophet wrote about me in the scriptures" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

The apostles would have understood that God would cause everything written in the scriptures to happen. AT: "God will fulfill" or "God will cause to happen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: he was regarded as one of the lawless
tn.text: Here Jesus is quoting the scriptures. This can be stated in active form. AT: "people considered him to be one of the lawless people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"those who break the law" or "the criminals"

tn.ref: For what is predicted about me is being fulfilled
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "For what the prophet predicted about me is about to happen" or 2) "For my life is coming to an end" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This refers to at least two of Jesus' apostles.

Possible meanings are 1) "That is enough swords" or 2) "That is enough talk about this." When Jesus said that they should buy swords, he was mainly telling them about the danger they would all face. He may not have really wanted them to buy swords and fight.
This is the next part of the story. Jesus went to the Mount of Olives to pray.
This refers to the completion of the Passover meal.

tn.ref: that you do not enter into temptation
tn.text: "that you are not tempted" or "that nothing tempts you and causes you to sin"
"about the distance that someone can throw a stone." AT: "a short distance" or with an estimated measurement like "about thirty meters" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Jesus will bear the guilt of every person's sin on the cross. He prays to his Father asking if there is another way.
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

Jesus refers to the suffering that he is about to endure as if it were in a cup and that he was going to drink it. AT: "take away from me this cup of suffering" or "take away this suffering from me" or "rescue me from having to suffer like this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Nevertheless not my will, but yours be done
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "However, do what is according to your will rather than doing what is according to my will" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"appeared to Jesus"
"encouraging him"
"He was suffering greatly, and so he prayed"
"he prayed more intensely" (UDB)

tn.ref: his sweat became like great drops of blood falling down upon the ground
tn.text: "his sweat was falling to the ground like large drops of blood"

tn.ref: When he rose up from his prayer
tn.text: "When Jesus got up after praying" or "After praying, Jesus got up and"

tn.ref: found them sleeping because of their sorrow
tn.text: "saw that they were sleeping because they were tired from their sadness"
Possible meanings are 1) "I am surprised that you are sleeping now" or 2) "You should not be sleeping now!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: that you may not enter into temptation
tn.text: "so that you may not be tempted" or "so that nothing tempts you and causes you to sin"
The word "behold" alerts us to a new group in the story. Your language may have a way of doing this. AT: "there was a crowd that appeared" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
Judas was showing the people where Jesus was. He was not telling the crowd what to do. AT: "leading them to Jesus"

"to greet him with a kiss" or "to greet him by kissing him." When men greeted other men who were family or friends, they would kiss them on one cheek or both cheeks. If your readers would find it embarrassing to say that a man would kiss another man, you could translate it in a more general way: "to give him a friendly greeting" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: are you betraying the Son of Man with a kiss?
tn.text: Jesus uses a question to rebuke Judas for betraying him with a kiss. Normally a kiss is a sign of love. AT: "it is a kiss you are using to betray the Son of Man!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Jesus is using this term to refer to himself. AT: "me, the Son of Man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
This refers to Jesus' disciples.
This refers to the priests and soldiers coming to arrest Jesus.
"fight against them with a sword"
"one of the disciples"

tn.ref: struck the servant of the high priest
tn.text: "struck the servant of the high priest with a sword"
This expression means, "Do not do any more of that!" (UDB)
"touched the servant where his ear had been cut off"

tn.ref: Do you come out as against a robber, with swords and clubs?
tn.text: "Do you come out with swords and clubs because you think I am a robber?" Jesus uses this question to scold the Jewish leaders. AT: "You know that I am not a robber, yet you come out to me bringing swords and clubs" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"I was among you every day"
Only priests entered the temple. AT: "in the temple courts" or "at the temple"
This expression refers to people exercising authority over the disciples. AT: "arrest me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"your time" or "your time to act"
It may be helpful to repeat the reference to time. AT: "and the time of the authority of darkness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
This refers to the evil ruler, Satan. AT: "the time of the ruler of darkness" or "the time for Satan to act" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"led Jesus away from the garden where they had arrested him"
"into the courtyard of the high priest's house"
"some people had made a fire." The fire was to keep the people warm during the cool night. AT: "some people started a fire to keep warm"
This was the courtyard at the high priest's house. It had walls around it, but no roof.
"together with them"

tn.ref: looked straight at him and said
tn.text: "looked straight at Peter and said to the other people in the courtyard"

tn.ref: This man also was with him
tn.text: The woman was telling the people about Peter being with Jesus. She probably did not know Peter's name.
"But Peter said that it was not true"

tn.ref: Woman, I do not know him
tn.text: Peter did not know the woman's name. He was not insulting her by calling her "woman." If people would think he was insulting her, you could use a culturally acceptable way for a man to address a woman he does not know, or you could leave out the word.

tn.ref: You are also one of them
tn.text: "You are one of the disciples of Jesus also"

Peter did not know the man's name. He was not insulting him by calling him "Man." If people would think he was insulting him, you could use a culturally acceptable way for a man to address a man he does not know, or you could leave out the word.
"said insistently" or "said loudly" (UDB)
Here "this man" refers to Peter. The speaker probably did not know Peter's name.
The man could probably tell Peter was from Galilee from the way he talked. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Peter did not know the man's name. He was not insulting him by calling him "Man." If people would think he was insulting him, you could use a culturally acceptable way for a man to address a man he does not know, or you could leave out the word. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:luk:22:56|22:58]].

tn.ref: I do not know what you are saying
tn.text: "I do not know what you are taking about." This expression means that Peter completely disagree with the man. AT: "what you said is not true at all" or "what you said is completely false" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"while Peter was speaking"
Roosters often crow just before the sun appears in the morning. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:luk:22:33|22:34]].

tn.ref: Turning, the Lord looked at Peter
tn.text: "The Lord turned and looked at Peter"
Jesus' "word" is here used to refer to everything that he said. AT: "Jesus' words" or "what Jesus had said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Roosters often crow just before the sun appears in the morning. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:luk:22:33|22:34]].

The Jewish day started at sundown and continued to the next evening. Jesus had spoken the previous evening about what would happen shortly before dawn or at dawn. AT: "tonight" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"deny three times that you know me"
"Going out of the courtyard"

tn.ref: They put a cover over him
tn.text: "They covered his eyes so that he could not see"

tn.ref: Prophesy! Who is the one who hit you?
tn.text: The guards did not believe that Jesus was a prophet. Rather they believed that a real prophet would know who hit him even if he could not see it. They called Jesus a prophet, but they wanted to show that he was not a prophet. AT: "Prove that you are a prophet. Tell us who hit you!" or "Hey prophet, who hit you?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
"Speak words from God!" The implied information is that God would have to tell Jesus who struck him since Jesus was blindfolded and could not see. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is now the next day and Jesus is brought before the council.

tn.ref: As soon as it was day
tn.text: "At dawn the next morning" (UDB)

tn.ref: They led him into the council
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "The elders had Jesus brought into the council" or 2) "The guards led Jesus into the council of the elders." Some languages may avoid saying who led him by using the pronoun "they" (ULB) or by using a passive verb: "Jesus was led into the council" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be translated as a new sentence. AT: "The elders said to Jesus"
"tell us that you are the Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: If I tell you ... if I ask you
tn.text: Jesus is saying that it did not matter whether he spoke or asked them to speak, they would not respond correctly. These two phrases together express Jesus' attitude that the council was not really looking for the truth.

tn.ref: If I tell you, you will not believe
tn.text: This is the first of two hypothetical statements by Jesus. It was a way for Jesus to respond without giving them a reason to say that he was guilty of blasphemy. Your language may have a way of indicating that the action has not actually happened. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: if I ask you, you will not answer
tn.text: This is the second hypothetical statement. It was a way for Jesus to rebuke them without giving them a reason to convict him. Your language may have a way of indicating that the action has not actually happened. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
Jesus continues speaking to the council.
"from this day" or "starting from today"

Jesus used this phrase to refer to himself. This title also referred to the Christ, but the elders would have to ask to verify that he was claiming to be the Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: seated at the right hand of the power of God
tn.text: The Jews understood that only God could sit there. They considered this equal to saying "will be with God as God."
"the all-powerful God." Here "power" refers to his supreme authority. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Then you are the Son of God?
tn.text: The council asked this question because they wanted Jesus to explicitly confirm their understanding that he was saying he was the Son of God. AT: "So when you said that, did you mean that you are the Son of God?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is an important title for Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
"Yes, it is just like you say" (UDB)

tn.ref: Why do we still need a witness?
tn.text: They use a question for emphasis. AT: "We have no further need for witnesses!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The phrase "his own mouth" refers to his speech. AT: "heard him say that he believes he is the Son of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
